headline: FALSE: This image does not show TPLF, Sudanese or Egyptian troops trying to enter Ethiopia
author: PesaCheck
description: The image has been uploaded to different websites since 2020 and is associated with reports of the border dispute between Ethiopia and…
articleBody:
An image posted on Facebook with a claim that it shows the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), along with Sudanese and Egyptian troops attempting to enter Ethiopia through Sudan is FALSE.

The post is accompanied by text in Amharic that reads in part,

“Action was taken by the Ethiopian Coalition forces on the troops trained in Sudan and sent to Ethiopia by TPLF. The TPLF was trying to deploy 6,000 troops, including Sudanese and Egyptian troops, through Sudan. Following these Sudan is telling the Ethiopian and Eritrean joint forces were attacking its troops,” parts of the post in Amharic reads.

However, Google reverse image search results reveal that the image has been used on different websites since 2020.

For instance, the image was published on the Hawar News Agency website on 18 December 2020 in an article: “Sudanese army declares control over all Sudanese lands.” Similarly, the image was used, as seen here and here, on the Archyde and Somali Guardian websites in their report about border disputes between Ethiopia and Sudan.

The Ethiopian government has said that it destroyed TPLF troops trying to enter Ethiopia through the Sudan border. But it did not mention the involvement of Sudanese and Egyptian armies. Also, the Sudan Tribune reported the attack yet it did not mention Eritrean troops involvement.

Ethiopia and Sudan have a border dispute over Al-Fashaga, fertile agricultural land. However, the image under investigation does not show the recent fighting between the two countries.

PesaCheck has looked into a Facebook image claiming to show TPLF, Sudanese, and Egyptian troops who are trying to enter Ethiopia through Sudan and find it to be FALSE.

headline: HOAX: This screenshot of a post credited to Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau is fake
author: PesaCheck
description: The original post does not appear on the verified page of the bureau.
articleBody:
This screenshot of a post allegedly shared by the Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau verified Facebook page is FAKE.

The post shared along with the screenshot reads, “Tigray forces admitted the death of General Tadesse Werede although they misrepresented the cause of his death”.

The screenshot, which mimics the profile picture, name and verification status of the Bureau’s verified page, contains four different photos of General Tadesse Werede, a chief commander of the Tigray Defense Force (TDF), a force fighting against the Ethiopian government troops.

The text on the screenshot reads in part, “The commander of TDF General Tadesse Werede (Wedi Werede) has passed away from a disease he had contracted”.

“We hereby notify that the claim made by the fascist leaders that they had killed him is false propaganda and would like to express our condolences to our people,” it adds.

On 4 December 2021, the Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau published on its verified Facebook page a communique, attributed to Lieutenant General Tadesse Werede, the TDF Commander-in-Chief General. In the statement, Tadesse noted that the TDF had pulled out from the areas it controlled in the Amhara region for strategic reasons.

The English version of the communique was shared on the Eritrea Hub, an online information site about Eritrea and the Horn of Africa.

The screenshot of the alleged post by Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau was shared on Facebook a day after Tadesse’s statement appeared.

However, PesaCheck has found that the screenshot is fake.

A review of the Tigray Communications Affair Bureau verified page reveals there is no such post.

Moreover, there is no news report on the claimed death of the TDF commander on both local and international online media outlets.

PesaCheck has investigated a screenshot of a post allegedly shared on the Tigray Communications Affair Bureau verified Facebook page and finds it to be a FAKE.

headline: SCAM: This website giving away KSh 7,000 Safaricom gift vouchers is a hoax
author: PesaCheck
description: There is no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s official website.
articleBody:
A website claiming to belong to Safaricom, and promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers is a SCAM.

Before being awarded the gift voucher, respondents have to answer a set of questions about themselves and their opinion of the Safaricom brand.

After completing the questionnaire, the user is informed that they have won a KSh 7,000 gift voucher. The only caveat is that they have to share the promotion with either five groups or 20 friends on WhatsApp.

“Share it until the blue bar is full!” a pop-up on the page reads.

This fact-checker pressed the ‘WhatsApp’ share button until the bar turned blue. The next step is to click the buttons ‘activate’ and ‘verify’. Verification is by keying in your phone number.

“Click activate and complete the given task, verification is by phone number or downloading, registering e.t.c. (Remember, this step is very important, add your phone number to verify),” the pop-up box reads.

This appears to be a phishing scam aimed at obtaining people’s personal information.

Clicking on the ‘activate’ and ‘verify’ buttons redirects to unrelated websites. One is an e-commerce site and the other is a Jumia black Friday promotion site.

To confirm whether the website we are fact-checking belongs to Safaricom, we visited the telecom’s verified Twitter account and clicked on the link on their bio. The link landed us on a completely different website.

WhoIs results show that the website being fact-checked was registered on 11 October 2021 under the domain name “mpesaken.gifts” in Iceland (IS).

Safaricom’s website, whose link is contained on the company’s verified Twitter account, was registered on 12 February 2003 under the domain name “safaricom.co.ke” in Kenya.

Scrolling through the official Safaricom website, did not return any cash giveaway. There is also no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s verified Twitter account or Facebook page.

PesaCheck has looked into a website claiming to belong to Safaricom, promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers and finds it to be a SCAM.

headline: FALSE: Tigray regional president Debretsion Gebremichael is not dead
author: PesaCheck
description: Debretsion Gebremichael appeared on Tigray TV on 6 December 2021.
articleBody:
A 3 December 2021 video shared on Facebook claiming that Debretsion Gebremichael, the president of the Tigray region, is dead, is FALSE.

“Breaking news. Debretsion’s funeral. Mekelle burst into tears,” the text of the video says in Amharic. It claims Debretsion’s funeral ceremony was held in Mekelle and the Tigray forces were concealing information about his death.

However, Debretsion appeared on Tigray TV on 6 December 2021, days after the death claims were made.

PesaCheck debunked similar death claims about Debretsion on 28 October 2021 and 29 October 2021, as seen here and here.

The Ethiopian National Defence Force has been at war with Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) forces in the north of the country since November 2020.

Some TPLF leaders have been killed as a result of the war.

Initially, the war was confined to the Tigray region, but it expanded to the Afar and Amhara regions. In early November 2021, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed announced he would go on the battlefront and it has since been reported that the Ethiopian government has recaptured many areas under Tigray Forces control.

PesaCheck has looked into a video post shared on Facebook on 3 December 2021 claiming the death of the Tigray region president, Debretsion Gebremichael, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: FAUX : Cette image ne montre pas l’épée du prophète Mohamed de l’islam
author: PesaCheck
description: Les archives historiques montrent que l’épée a appartenu au roi Boabdil qui a régné sur une partie de l’Espagne de 1237 à 1492.
articleBody:
Un post Facebook prétendant montrer une épée appartenant au prophète Mohamed de l’islam est FAUX.

Le post publié le 8 novembre 2021 montre une épée dont la poignée est en argent doré au mercure et recouverte d’un décor réalisé en filigrane avec son fourreau fixés côte-à-côte sur un support.

D’après l’auteur du post, l’épée appartenait au « messager d’Allah SAW — Abū al-Qāsim Muḥammad ibn, fondateur de l’islam. » D’autres publications indiquent par contre qu’il s’agit d’une épée qui a appartenu au plus grand guerrier hindou Maharana Pratap du XVIe siècle.

PesaCheck a enquêté sur le post viral et a trouvé que l’épée n’appartient ni au prophète Mahomet ni au guerrier hindou Maharana Pratap.

Une recherche par image inversée sur Google conduit vers des sources qui élucident l’histoire autour de cette épée appelée « Boabdil » ou « épée de cavalier. » D’après le magazine Quatara dédié à la culture arabe, l’épée sur la photo du post trompeur a appartenu au roi Mohammed XII de Grenade, aussi connu sous le nom du sultan Boabdil (Abû Abdil-lah) de la dynastie nasride qui a régné sur l’Espagne du XIIIe au XVe siècle.

La Bibliothèque nationale de France (BNF) confirme l’information sur son site web en expliquant que l’épée a bel et bien appartenu au sultan Boabdil, mais, « n’a plus sa lame d’origine, qui devait comporter un décor ciselé ou incrusté. »

Long de 97 centimètres, l’épée de Boabdil est conservée au musée de l’armée en Espagne. L’épée montrée dans la publication n’appartient pas au prophète Mohamed de l’islam.

PesaCheck a examiné une image d’un post prétendant montrer une épée appartenant au prophète Mohamed et a trouvé que c’était FAUX.

headline: ALTERED: This image of fighters with the Oromo Liberation flag is doctored
author: PesaCheck
description: The original image shows Somali Al Shabaab fighters gathering in February 2012.
articleBody:
An image post of armed personnel in which a Facebook user claims it shows the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) soldiers is ALTERED.

The post in Amharic has a headline that says, “the OLF Shane group has been eliminated”.

“OLF shene, the group that allied with TPLF Junta to destabilise the country has been operating in some of Oromia regions, but its mission is being aborted,” the post reads in part, adding “irreversible actions were taken against the destabilizing force which planned to carry out terrorist actions in East Guji, Negelle Borana and Arsi Negelle areas”.

The photo shows an armed group in military uniform standing in two lines, their heads covered with black scarves, while one holds up an OLF flag.

The names OLF Shane and Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) are widely used to refer to an armed group fighting against national troops in the Oromia regional state.

Reports by the Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation, a state-owned broadcaster, seen here, here and here, say that coordinated action had been taken by Federal Police and Oromia special forces against OLF Shane on 8 December 2021.

The social media user copied the state broadcast news and shared it along with the image in the post.

However, the attached image does not show OLF Shane or OLA, as claimed.

Google reverse image search results show that the image shows a gathering of Somali Al Shabaab fighters in February 2012. The photo has been used in multiple news stories since then.

The image was captured by AFP photographer Mohamed Abdiwahab on 13 February 2012 at Elasha Biyaha in Somalia. The description of the image provides that the image is of “Somali Al Shebab (sic) fighters” gathering in Elasha Biyaha, in Somalia, after a demonstration to support the merger of Al Shebab and the Al-Qaeda network.

The original image was digitally manipulated and the Al Shabaab fighters’ flag was replaced by that of the OLF.

PesaCheck has investigated an image shared on Facebook claiming to show fighters of the Oromo Liberation Army and finds it to be ALTERED.

headline: FALSE: These photos do not show roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention
author: PesaCheck
description: The images of roads in the tweet are from Brazil and Uganda.
articleBody:
A tweet with images claiming to show a before and after look of the roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) after Uganda’s intervention is MISLEADING.

The tweet reads; “DR Congo Roads before Uganda intervention vs soon after our intervention. #LetsBuildUG”.

The image purporting to show DRC before Uganda’s intervention is a dirt road in which several vehicles are stuck, while the one claiming to show the aftermath of Kampala’s intervention is a tarmacked road with limited traffic.

However, a Google reverse image search shows the first photo was taken from the Amazon region in Brazil. The image has been featured in several publications online, including here, here and here.

The search also reveals that the image was taken on the Trans-Amazonian highway. This 5,000-kilometre road cuts across the heart of the Amazon forest, spanning Brazil from the coastal city of João Pessoa in the northeast to the border with Peru.

A Google reverse image search shows the second picture was taken from Uganda in Mpigi District. The Uganda National Roads Authority first shared the photo on Twitter, showing the Mpigi — Kanoni road project.

The post follows Uganda’s announcement of a plan to build 223km of roads in neighbouring DRC, premised on boosting trade between the two countries. However, none of the images above shows a road in the DRC.

PesaCheck has looked into a tweet with images claiming to be taken from the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention and finds them to be FALSE.

headline: FALSE: David Ndii did not pen this letter resigning as the economic advisor of Kenya’s deputy president
author: PesaCheck
description: Ndii has refuted the claim, saying the only open letter he has written recently is addressed to President Uhuru Kenyatta.
articleBody:
An open letter shared on Facebook signed with the name of economist David Ndii and announcing his resignation as the economic advisor of Deputy President William Ruto, is FALSE.

The letter titled “Open Letter to the Deputy President William Ruto” is dated 7 December 2021 and appears to contain the signature of Ndii.

In the letter, Ndii explains his resignation was motivated by a sequence of personal reflection and thought-provoking reviews, adding that his two main reasons were “political conmanship and corruption.”

“Having originated the concept of bottom-up economic model, which seeks to uplift the proletariats which was also in the NASA 2017 campaigns, I have come to realize that my position as UDA’S economic strategist is untenable,” reads part of the letter.

The document accuses the deputy president of using the bottom-up economic model for the sole intent of capturing power, further alleging that Ruto is “the cause of the economic distress the country is facing”.

“In view of the aforesaid, it is my belief that you do not represent the common Mwananchi’s political and economic aspirations… you are a continuation of the economic oppressors that were bred under the KANU regime in the 90s and have now morphed in disguise as an economic liberator,” adds the letter.

However, there is no information about the letter on Ndii’s Twitter account where he routinely posts his stance on various political issues.

In a Twitter thread on 7 December 2021, Ndii disowned the letter, saying that the only open letter he has written recently was addressed to President Uhuru Kenyatta.

The letter from Ndii to the head of state is dated, 25 March 2020 and contains suggestions on what the president should do to effectively address the COVID-19 pandemic.

PesaCheck has examined the open letter shared on Facebook claiming to have been authored by economist David Ndii and announcing his resignation from his position as economic advisor to Deputy President William Ruto, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: FALSE: Ignore this message inviting applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya — it is fabricated
author: PesaCheck
description: The automobile marketer has disowned the message and confirmed that it is fake.
articleBody:
A Facebook post asking job seekers to submit applications for vacancies at Isuzu Kenya is FALSE.

The company is urgently looking for technicians, the post states, and those with a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering are eligible to apply. The email address given for communication appears to be hosted on the same domain as the actual Isuzi Kenya domain — isuzu.co.ke and interested candidates are asked to send their applications to the address.

“If you happen yo (sic) know anybody with a KNEC diploma in mechanical engineering, Automotive or production options with a minimum score of C- (Minus) kindly assist them to forward their photocopy documents to: ISUZU E.A (Formerly General Motors) for shortlisting. Please treat this with maximum urgency as technicians are urgently required,” reads the message.

The message has also been shared here.

However, there is no information about the job opportunity on the company’s website, its Facebook and Twitter accounts.

In a Facebook post on 6 December 2021, the company disowned the message, terming it as fake.

Additionally, applications for job opportunities at Isuzu Kenya are sent to [email protected] and not to specific individuals as claimed.

PesaCheck has examined a message calling on job seekers to submit applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: Fact-checking statistics about Kenya’s ‘boda boda’ transport sector
author: Simon Muli
description: How accurate are claims that 500,000 motorcycles are in the ‘boda boda’ business in Kenya and that 76,000 unregistered ‘boda boda’…
articleBody:
Gabriel Oguda claimed there are 500,000 motorcycles in the ‘boda boda’ business, with 16,500 units imported every month, and 76,000 unregistered operators in Nairobi alone.

Mr Oguda further claimed 1,075 people died from boda boda accidents in 2020 alone — 301 pillion passengers (a passenger that sits behind the rider on a motorbike) and 774 motorcyclists.

However, the source of these statistics was not quoted, despite a query from one of the users who responded to Mr Oguda’s tweet.

‘Boda bodas’ are two-wheeler commercial motorcycles that have become a popular mode of transport both in the Kenyan rural areas and urban sprawls, moving people and goods from one place to another. They have especially been entrenched in the Kenyan transport infrastructure aside from serving as a source of employment and livelihood to many.

So, the question is, how true are the statistics tweeted by Gabriel Oguda about ‘boda bodas’ in Kenya?

PesaCheck has examined all the four claims and found out the following:

On July 18, 2020, the National Transport and Safety Authority (NTSA) began registering all boda boda operators in Kenya in a move aimed at reducing accidents and curbing criminal activities involving motorbikes.

This suggests that there is no official database with details on the exact number of motorcycles in the boda boda business, as confirmed in a 2018 report by the National Crime Research Centre (NCRC) — a State Corporation under the Ministry of Interior and Coordination of National Government.

“The National Transport and Safety Authority (NTSA) reported that there were 1,393,390 motorcycles registered in Kenya as at February 2018. However, the exact numbers of these motorcycles operating as ‘boda bodas’ in the country is not known and documented.

The lacuna in policy regarding the registration, regulation, monitoring and use of motorcycles in boda boda public service vehicle (PSV) transport is a cause for alarm,” read the report.

Another report by the NCRC in 2019 recommended the establishment of a database of all boda boda operators in Kenya through mandatory registration, refresher training and testing.

According to the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics’ (KNBS) Economic Survey 2020 and 2015, the combined total of the number of registered motor and auto cycles over the last 10 years is 1,427,533. Both surveys make no mention of how many of these imported units are used as boda bodas.

The Motorcycle Assemblers Association of Kenya (MAAK) told PesaCheck in an email response it estimates that there are about 900,000 motorcycles in Kenya in the boda boda business.

However, the figures by MAAK do not take into account those units that are directly imported into the country or those that are bought for personal use; rather, only those that are assembled locally.

The National Chairman of Boda Boda Safety Association of Kenya, Kevin Mubadi, told PesaCheck that there are 1.4 million boda bodas in Kenya. Again this is also an estimated figure, based on media reports and pronouncements by government officials.

“We are rolling out massive registration to ensure that all of them are digitally registered,” Mr Mubadi said. However, he did not give a timeline on when this would be conducted.

According to UNLEASH, a non-profit founded in 2016, the boda boda sector employs over 1.2 million youth.

Based on the available evidence, the claim that there are 500,000 motorcycles in the boda boda business is therefore MOSTLY FALSE.

Claim 2: There are 76, 000 unregistered operators in Nairobi alone.

Verdict — INCONCLUSIVE

The 2018 report by the NCRC pointed out that the issue of unregistered motorcycles is one of the major impediments to addressing the issue of run-away crime plaguing the sub-sector.

Another report carried on CitizenTV in 2019, claimed an estimated 45,000 motorcycles that year were waiting for number plates but were already in use. The report attributed the figures to Motorcycle Assemblers of Kenya Chairman Isaac Kalua.

But apart from speculative news reports, there are no definitive figures about unregistered motorcycles making the claim INCONCLUSIVE.

The 2020 Economic Survey by the KNBS shows that newly registered motorcycles numbered 210,103 units in 2019. This works out to about 17,508 units per month.

The monthly average of the same for the preceding year (2018) was 15,749 and the year before that (2017) stood at 15,536.

Based on the annual figures of newly registered motorcycles between 2017 to 2019, the monthly average number of motorcycle units imported over the past three years works out to about 16,264.

So the claim that 16,500 motorcycle units are imported every month largely holds true.

Magdaline Karigu, an official at the Motorcycle Assemblers Association of Kenya (MAAK), also told PesaCheck in an email that currently, an average of 18,000 motorcycles are registered monthly in Kenya.

The available evidence, therefore, makes the claim that 16,500 motorcycle units are imported every month MOSTLY TRUE.

Claim 4: 1,075 people already died from ‘boda boda’ accidents in 2020 alone with 301 of those being pillion passengers and 774 being motorcyclists.

Verdict — TRUE

The figures mentioned in the claim are taken from a statement released by NTSA dated October 9, 2020, and which was published jointly with the National Police Service.

In the latest figures released on November 11, 2020, the NTSA said that 884 motorcyclists and 350 pillion passengers died from ‘boda boda’ accidents bringing the total fatalities to 1,244.

Given that the claim in question was posted on October 18, it is therefore TRUE.

headline: How PesaCheck works
author: PesaCheck
description: [Updated: 18 December 2020]
articleBody:
PesaCheck is headed by a publisher, who is also CfA’s chief executive officer (and co-founder). The publisher drives organisational strategy, and partnerships. The newsroom is led by a managing editor, who is the senior editorial decision-maker and who is responsible for shaping editorial priorities and signing-off on all fact-checks before publication. The managing editor is assisted by three deputy editors; a news editor who manages the NewsDesk and in-country researchers/fact-checkers across the continent; a chief copy editor who manages the multilingual CopyDesk that uses a three-step process to check all fact-checks for factual accuracy and grammatical correctness; and a special projects editor who oversees PesaCheck’s digital innovations including our DebunkBot, PromiseTracker, PesaYetu and TaxClock toolkits.

The editors are supported by deputies (including Francophone and Amharic language team coordinators), as well as newsdesk-based specialist data analysts/researchers.

The PesaCheck newsdesk receives additional support from CfA’s wider data journalism and infographic design teams, as well as its digital engagement (social media and multimedia) team. And, PesaCheck works closely with CfA’s Academy to help mentor and train other newsrooms or civic watchdogs.

Our researchers

PesaCheck’s editorial team is composed of fact-checkers who have extensive journalistic experience, or who are research specialists in topics such as economics, public finances or development issues.

Our fact-checkers are always locally based, in the 12 countries we report from, in Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Côte d’Ivoire, Ethiopia, Guinea, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Tanzania and Uganda. We also run a Francophone regional support hub in Senegal.

The fact-checkers regularly collaborate on regional verification projects, tackling cross-cutting thematic issues such as the COVID-19 health emergency, or assisting each other as part of ‘rapid response teams’ during civil wars/conflicts/coups and during the run-up/polling during elections.

PesaCheck occasionally appoints additional specialists, as short-term ‘fellows’ or associates, to drive specific projects such as our research into persistent conspiracy theories on YouTube or the spread of toxic speech (such as racist incitement and other hate speech) on WhatsApp.

PesaCheck’s fact-checkers focus on verifying the accuracy and meaning of the actual content in mis-/disinformation claims. Another CfA initiative, the iLAB at ANCIR, uses data science and forensic investigation to probe the ‘hidden hand’ networks and digital techniques used to make misleading content go viral. PesaCheck often collaborates with the iLAB and another CfA incubated initiative, the Digital Forensic Labs (DFRLab) Africa team, to expose large-scale coordinated inauthentic behaviour (CiB) and influence operations.

More information on the core PesaCheck team can be found here.

Our sources

There is a lot of mis-/disinformation and other misleading content out there. This includes claims by public figures and pundits at public events and in the mainstream media (in print media, or on TV and radio, and on their online outlets), as well as on government or political party websites, on social media (including on chat platforms such as WhatsApp) or blogging and multimedia sites such as YouTube.

PesaCheck believes it is important to apply a consistent set of criteria for determining eligibility for us to fact-check public claims, so that we can be consistently even-handed in our approach.

We also collect requests from the public on claims that need checking using this online form.

As a requirement for all our fact-checks, we include multiple sources of information and references. This helps to underline the veracity of our arguments. In addition, the sources are referenced accurately. To do this, we use sourceAFRICA, a repository of actionable documents.

Through sourceAFRICA, the PesaCheck team can:

Archive the source documents for future reference
Annotate the specific page where the information is sourced from. As newspapers do not use complete references like academic papers, hyperlinks would serve to highlight the references. It also allows the readers an opportunity to review the document in its entirety.

Every source document that is referenced in a story is saved on sourceAFRICA in order to preserve a copy and link directly to the information being referenced.

All sources and facts to be checked will be recorded on Check, where fact-check requests crowdsourced from the public and from social media will be managed and updated as they progress.

We put a premium on story ideas generated by members of the public, as this indicates that the issue is of great public importance, and it is a good source of information that may not yet be in the public eye.

To underline the credibility of PesaCheck stories, we ensure that our sources are quoted comprehensively — full name and designation.

Any information from sources that seek anonymity is treated as background information only. Such information must be corroborated by evidence.

PesaCheck is committed to disclosing to its readers the sources of the information in its stories to the maximum possible extent. We want to make our reporting as transparent to the readers as possible so they may know how and where we got our information. Transparency is honest and fair, two values we cherish.

Identifying claims to be checked

Not all statements are created equal. Here are some criteria that we use to help establish a hierarchy of important statements to fact-check:

Members of the public can also suggest claims to be fact-checked, by emailing us at [email protected] or reach the news editor at [email protected] They can also WhatsApp out tipline: +254754999992. If claims from the public meet the public interest criteria, they’ll be looked into, and feedback provided on the channel it was shared.

Fact-checking guidelines

We have three main rules guiding our fact-checking process:

Golden Rule 1: Only one fact per fact-check. We limit each fact check to one statement only, or a set of statements that are clearly related.
Golden Rule 2: Check every fact check. We do our best to corroborate the fact/verification. For example, rather than using a newspaper story about the budget; we use the budget document to fact check a statement.
Golden Rule 3: Draw a conclusion based on the facts. After all the research, corroboration and interviews, we assign a label to the fact check: True, Partially True, Untrue, Partially Untrue, or Inconclusive.

We use this checklist to write and prepare our fact-checks:

Is the statement being checked included verbatim?
Is there an explainer for why this statement was selected for checking?
Has the category of deception been identified?
Have all the sources for the fact being checked been identified?
Any source documents used in the fact check need to be annotated and uploaded to sourceAfrica, including any additional useful data identified in the process of fact-checking.
Has the reason for the labeling the statement True, Not True, etc been indicated?
Is the label (true, not true etc) mentioned briefly at the top of the story, and in more detail at the end of the story?
Have any links to the sources and the statement being checked been included in the body of the article?

Final editing checklist

We use the following final editing checklist based in part on the PolitiFact checklist:

1. Is the claim open to interpretation? Is there another way to read the claim?

2. Is the rating fair and consistent with other fact checks?

3. Is the rating supported by all available facts? Do questions linger?

Social media policy

Social media is a key tool that we use to distribute our fact-checks. The following are guidelines that we use to keep our social media consistent and harmonised.

We don’t post anything that we cannot stand by.
All posts follow a consistent structure — a question statement (what), a source (who) and a link to the story (where to find more).
Example: FACT CHECK: Did @Kandie_Phyllis misspeak about pledging Sh18bn for disabled kids? @PesaCheck finds out: p://bit.ly/2aIxrqa
Each fact check needs a standard hashtag, for example #PesaCheck
All reactions and comments are looked into, especially when they lead to potential follow-up stories that may arise out of the fact check.

Corrections policy

Transparency is a core value for PesaCheck, and we strive for accurate and comprehensive fact-checking. We all make mistakes sometimes, and while every error is a weakness, some errors are inevitable, and we are fully open to correcting them promptly in whatever material we publish on our platforms.

When we run a correction, clarification or editor’s note, our goal is to tell readers, as clearly and quickly as possible, what was wrong and what is correct. Anyone should be able to understand how and why a mistake has been corrected.

It is necessary to use a correction, clarification or editor’s note to inform readers whenever we correct a significant mistake.

Updates are used to reflect important new information or clarifications; corrections are for mistakes.

Clarification

When the content is factually correct but the language used to explain the facts is not as clear or detailed as it should be, the post will be rewritten and a clarification added to the story. A clarification can also be used to note that we initially failed to seek a comment or response that has since been added to the story.

Editor’s notes

A correction that calls into question the entire substance of an article, raises a significant ethical matter or addresses whether an article did not meet our standards, may require an Editor’s Note and be followed by an explanation of what is at issue.

Therefore:

When an error is brought to our attention, we will indicate in comments that it has been corrected.
Any erroneous information published on our social platforms will be corrected on any and all platforms it was published on.
We do not attribute blame to individuals, but we may note that an error was the result of incorrect information from a trusted source.

Take-down (unpublish) requests

As a matter of editorial policy, we do not grant take-down requests. If the subject claims that the story was inaccurate, we are prepared to investigate and, if necessary, publish a correction.

Stories will be updated if we checked a claim and drew a conclusion based on facts available at the time, but there is significant new information that will warrant a change in that conclusion.

In short, our response will be to consider whether further action is warranted, but not to remove the article as though it had never been published.

Right of reply

Persons who are the subject of a fact-check get a reasonable opportunity to respond to us.

Attribution

We strive to be truthful about the source of our information. Facts and quotations in a story that were not produced by our own reporting need an attribution. Attribution of material from other media must be total. Plagiarism is not permitted.

We place a premium value on original reporting.

Persons who are the subject of a fact-check get a reasonable opportunity to respond to us.

We strive to be truthful about the source of our information. Facts and quotations in a story that were not produced by our own reporting need an attribution. Attribution of material from other media must be total. Plagiarism is not permitted.

headline: ALTERED: This image of fighters with the Oromo Liberation flag is doctored
author: PesaCheck
description: The original image shows Somali Al Shabaab fighters gathering in February 2012.
articleBody:
An image post of armed personnel in which a Facebook user claims it shows the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) soldiers is ALTERED.

The post in Amharic has a headline that says, “the OLF Shane group has been eliminated”.

“OLF shene, the group that allied with TPLF Junta to destabilise the country has been operating in some of Oromia regions, but its mission is being aborted,” the post reads in part, adding “irreversible actions were taken against the destabilizing force which planned to carry out terrorist actions in East Guji, Negelle Borana and Arsi Negelle areas”.

The photo shows an armed group in military uniform standing in two lines, their heads covered with black scarves, while one holds up an OLF flag.

The names OLF Shane and Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) are widely used to refer to an armed group fighting against national troops in the Oromia regional state.

Reports by the Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation, a state-owned broadcaster, seen here, here and here, say that coordinated action had been taken by Federal Police and Oromia special forces against OLF Shane on 8 December 2021.

The social media user copied the state broadcast news and shared it along with the image in the post.

However, the attached image does not show OLF Shane or OLA, as claimed.

Google reverse image search results show that the image shows a gathering of Somali Al Shabaab fighters in February 2012. The photo has been used in multiple news stories since then.

The image was captured by AFP photographer Mohamed Abdiwahab on 13 February 2012 at Elasha Biyaha in Somalia. The description of the image provides that the image is of “Somali Al Shebab (sic) fighters” gathering in Elasha Biyaha, in Somalia, after a demonstration to support the merger of Al Shebab and the Al-Qaeda network.

The original image was digitally manipulated and the Al Shabaab fighters’ flag was replaced by that of the OLF.

PesaCheck has investigated an image shared on Facebook claiming to show fighters of the Oromo Liberation Army and finds it to be ALTERED.

headline: HOAX: This screenshot of a post credited to Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau is fake
author: PesaCheck
description: The original post does not appear on the verified page of the bureau.
articleBody:
This screenshot of a post allegedly shared by the Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau verified Facebook page is FAKE.

The post shared along with the screenshot reads, “Tigray forces admitted the death of General Tadesse Werede although they misrepresented the cause of his death”.

The screenshot, which mimics the profile picture, name and verification status of the Bureau’s verified page, contains four different photos of General Tadesse Werede, a chief commander of the Tigray Defense Force (TDF), a force fighting against the Ethiopian government troops.

The text on the screenshot reads in part, “The commander of TDF General Tadesse Werede (Wedi Werede) has passed away from a disease he had contracted”.

“We hereby notify that the claim made by the fascist leaders that they had killed him is false propaganda and would like to express our condolences to our people,” it adds.

On 4 December 2021, the Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau published on its verified Facebook page a communique, attributed to Lieutenant General Tadesse Werede, the TDF Commander-in-Chief General. In the statement, Tadesse noted that the TDF had pulled out from the areas it controlled in the Amhara region for strategic reasons.

The English version of the communique was shared on the Eritrea Hub, an online information site about Eritrea and the Horn of Africa.

The screenshot of the alleged post by Tigray Communications Affairs Bureau was shared on Facebook a day after Tadesse’s statement appeared.

However, PesaCheck has found that the screenshot is fake.

A review of the Tigray Communications Affair Bureau verified page reveals there is no such post.

Moreover, there is no news report on the claimed death of the TDF commander on both local and international online media outlets.

PesaCheck has investigated a screenshot of a post allegedly shared on the Tigray Communications Affair Bureau verified Facebook page and finds it to be a FAKE.

headline: FALSE: These photos do not show roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention
author: PesaCheck
description: The images of roads in the tweet are from Brazil and Uganda.
articleBody:
A tweet with images claiming to show a before and after look of the roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) after Uganda’s intervention is MISLEADING.

The tweet reads; “DR Congo Roads before Uganda intervention vs soon after our intervention. #LetsBuildUG”.

The image purporting to show DRC before Uganda’s intervention is a dirt road in which several vehicles are stuck, while the one claiming to show the aftermath of Kampala’s intervention is a tarmacked road with limited traffic.

However, a Google reverse image search shows the first photo was taken from the Amazon region in Brazil. The image has been featured in several publications online, including here, here and here.

The search also reveals that the image was taken on the Trans-Amazonian highway. This 5,000-kilometre road cuts across the heart of the Amazon forest, spanning Brazil from the coastal city of João Pessoa in the northeast to the border with Peru.

A Google reverse image search shows the second picture was taken from Uganda in Mpigi District. The Uganda National Roads Authority first shared the photo on Twitter, showing the Mpigi — Kanoni road project.

The post follows Uganda’s announcement of a plan to build 223km of roads in neighbouring DRC, premised on boosting trade between the two countries. However, none of the images above shows a road in the DRC.

PesaCheck has looked into a tweet with images claiming to be taken from the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention and finds them to be FALSE.

headline: FALSE: Ignore this message inviting applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya — it is fabricated
author: PesaCheck
description: The automobile marketer has disowned the message and confirmed that it is fake.
articleBody:
A Facebook post asking job seekers to submit applications for vacancies at Isuzu Kenya is FALSE.

The company is urgently looking for technicians, the post states, and those with a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering are eligible to apply. The email address given for communication appears to be hosted on the same domain as the actual Isuzi Kenya domain — isuzu.co.ke and interested candidates are asked to send their applications to the address.

“If you happen yo (sic) know anybody with a KNEC diploma in mechanical engineering, Automotive or production options with a minimum score of C- (Minus) kindly assist them to forward their photocopy documents to: ISUZU E.A (Formerly General Motors) for shortlisting. Please treat this with maximum urgency as technicians are urgently required,” reads the message.

The message has also been shared here.

However, there is no information about the job opportunity on the company’s website, its Facebook and Twitter accounts.

In a Facebook post on 6 December 2021, the company disowned the message, terming it as fake.

Additionally, applications for job opportunities at Isuzu Kenya are sent to [email protected] and not to specific individuals as claimed.

PesaCheck has examined a message calling on job seekers to submit applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: FAUX : Cette image ne montre pas l’épée du prophète Mohamed de l’islam
author: PesaCheck
description: Les archives historiques montrent que l’épée a appartenu au roi Boabdil qui a régné sur une partie de l’Espagne de 1237 à 1492.
articleBody:
Un post Facebook prétendant montrer une épée appartenant au prophète Mohamed de l’islam est FAUX.

Le post publié le 8 novembre 2021 montre une épée dont la poignée est en argent doré au mercure et recouverte d’un décor réalisé en filigrane avec son fourreau fixés côte-à-côte sur un support.

D’après l’auteur du post, l’épée appartenait au « messager d’Allah SAW — Abū al-Qāsim Muḥammad ibn, fondateur de l’islam. » D’autres publications indiquent par contre qu’il s’agit d’une épée qui a appartenu au plus grand guerrier hindou Maharana Pratap du XVIe siècle.

PesaCheck a enquêté sur le post viral et a trouvé que l’épée n’appartient ni au prophète Mahomet ni au guerrier hindou Maharana Pratap.

Une recherche par image inversée sur Google conduit vers des sources qui élucident l’histoire autour de cette épée appelée « Boabdil » ou « épée de cavalier. » D’après le magazine Quatara dédié à la culture arabe, l’épée sur la photo du post trompeur a appartenu au roi Mohammed XII de Grenade, aussi connu sous le nom du sultan Boabdil (Abû Abdil-lah) de la dynastie nasride qui a régné sur l’Espagne du XIIIe au XVe siècle.

La Bibliothèque nationale de France (BNF) confirme l’information sur son site web en expliquant que l’épée a bel et bien appartenu au sultan Boabdil, mais, « n’a plus sa lame d’origine, qui devait comporter un décor ciselé ou incrusté. »

Long de 97 centimètres, l’épée de Boabdil est conservée au musée de l’armée en Espagne. L’épée montrée dans la publication n’appartient pas au prophète Mohamed de l’islam.

PesaCheck a examiné une image d’un post prétendant montrer une épée appartenant au prophète Mohamed et a trouvé que c’était FAUX.

headline: FALSE: David Ndii did not pen this letter resigning as the economic advisor of Kenya’s deputy president
author: PesaCheck
description: Ndii has refuted the claim, saying the only open letter he has written recently is addressed to President Uhuru Kenyatta.
articleBody:
An open letter shared on Facebook signed with the name of economist David Ndii and announcing his resignation as the economic advisor of Deputy President William Ruto, is FALSE.

The letter titled “Open Letter to the Deputy President William Ruto” is dated 7 December 2021 and appears to contain the signature of Ndii.

In the letter, Ndii explains his resignation was motivated by a sequence of personal reflection and thought-provoking reviews, adding that his two main reasons were “political conmanship and corruption.”

“Having originated the concept of bottom-up economic model, which seeks to uplift the proletariats which was also in the NASA 2017 campaigns, I have come to realize that my position as UDA’S economic strategist is untenable,” reads part of the letter.

The document accuses the deputy president of using the bottom-up economic model for the sole intent of capturing power, further alleging that Ruto is “the cause of the economic distress the country is facing”.

“In view of the aforesaid, it is my belief that you do not represent the common Mwananchi’s political and economic aspirations… you are a continuation of the economic oppressors that were bred under the KANU regime in the 90s and have now morphed in disguise as an economic liberator,” adds the letter.

However, there is no information about the letter on Ndii’s Twitter account where he routinely posts his stance on various political issues.

In a Twitter thread on 7 December 2021, Ndii disowned the letter, saying that the only open letter he has written recently was addressed to President Uhuru Kenyatta.

The letter from Ndii to the head of state is dated, 25 March 2020 and contains suggestions on what the president should do to effectively address the COVID-19 pandemic.

PesaCheck has examined the open letter shared on Facebook claiming to have been authored by economist David Ndii and announcing his resignation from his position as economic advisor to Deputy President William Ruto, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: FALSE: This image does not show TPLF, Sudanese or Egyptian troops trying to enter Ethiopia
author: PesaCheck
description: The image has been uploaded to different websites since 2020 and is associated with reports of the border dispute between Ethiopia and…
articleBody:
An image posted on Facebook with a claim that it shows the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), along with Sudanese and Egyptian troops attempting to enter Ethiopia through Sudan is FALSE.

The post is accompanied by text in Amharic that reads in part,

“Action was taken by the Ethiopian Coalition forces on the troops trained in Sudan and sent to Ethiopia by TPLF. The TPLF was trying to deploy 6,000 troops, including Sudanese and Egyptian troops, through Sudan. Following these Sudan is telling the Ethiopian and Eritrean joint forces were attacking its troops,” parts of the post in Amharic reads.

However, Google reverse image search results reveal that the image has been used on different websites since 2020.

For instance, the image was published on the Hawar News Agency website on 18 December 2020 in an article: “Sudanese army declares control over all Sudanese lands.” Similarly, the image was used, as seen here and here, on the Archyde and Somali Guardian websites in their report about border disputes between Ethiopia and Sudan.

The Ethiopian government has said that it destroyed TPLF troops trying to enter Ethiopia through the Sudan border. But it did not mention the involvement of Sudanese and Egyptian armies. Also, the Sudan Tribune reported the attack yet it did not mention Eritrean troops involvement.

Ethiopia and Sudan have a border dispute over Al-Fashaga, fertile agricultural land. However, the image under investigation does not show the recent fighting between the two countries.

PesaCheck has looked into a Facebook image claiming to show TPLF, Sudanese, and Egyptian troops who are trying to enter Ethiopia through Sudan and find it to be FALSE.

headline: SCAM: This website giving away KSh 7,000 Safaricom gift vouchers is a hoax
author: PesaCheck
description: There is no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s official website.
articleBody:
A website claiming to belong to Safaricom, and promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers is a SCAM.

Before being awarded the gift voucher, respondents have to answer a set of questions about themselves and their opinion of the Safaricom brand.

After completing the questionnaire, the user is informed that they have won a KSh 7,000 gift voucher. The only caveat is that they have to share the promotion with either five groups or 20 friends on WhatsApp.

“Share it until the blue bar is full!” a pop-up on the page reads.

This fact-checker pressed the ‘WhatsApp’ share button until the bar turned blue. The next step is to click the buttons ‘activate’ and ‘verify’. Verification is by keying in your phone number.

“Click activate and complete the given task, verification is by phone number or downloading, registering e.t.c. (Remember, this step is very important, add your phone number to verify),” the pop-up box reads.

This appears to be a phishing scam aimed at obtaining people’s personal information.

Clicking on the ‘activate’ and ‘verify’ buttons redirects to unrelated websites. One is an e-commerce site and the other is a Jumia black Friday promotion site.

To confirm whether the website we are fact-checking belongs to Safaricom, we visited the telecom’s verified Twitter account and clicked on the link on their bio. The link landed us on a completely different website.

WhoIs results show that the website being fact-checked was registered on 11 October 2021 under the domain name “mpesaken.gifts” in Iceland (IS).

Safaricom’s website, whose link is contained on the company’s verified Twitter account, was registered on 12 February 2003 under the domain name “safaricom.co.ke” in Kenya.

Scrolling through the official Safaricom website, did not return any cash giveaway. There is also no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s verified Twitter account or Facebook page.

PesaCheck has looked into a website claiming to belong to Safaricom, promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers and finds it to be a SCAM.

headline: FAKE: This Twitter account that flagged a KTN News post as fake news is an imposter
author: PesaCheck
description: Standard PLC’s digital editor, Caroline Kimutai, told PesaCheck that the story is not fake and is based on President Uhuru Kenyatta’s State…
articleBody:
Standard PLC’s digital editor, Caroline Kimutai, told PesaCheck that the story is not fake and is based on President Uhuru Kenyatta’s State of the Nation address.

A Twitter account, using the name KTN News, which has flagged a post by the authentic KTN News as false news, is FAKE.

In a lone tweet, the Twitter account claims that the post published by KTN News about the National Treasury’s warning about a looming financial crisis in Kenya is ‘fake news’.

“KTN Kenya would like to inform the public that it has no record of the Treasury Cabinet Secretary ever releasing any statements regarding the future state of the economy and would like to distance itself from it. Fake news this is,” the tweet claims.

On 2 December 2021, via its verified Twitter account, KTN News reported that Kenya’s National Treasury had warned of a looming financial crisis in Kenya due to the high level of debt.

“​​National Treasury has for the first time warned of a looming financial crisis as the level of debt threatens to surpass the country’s total economic output, or Gross Domestic Product (GDP),” KTN News tweeted.

headline: FALSE: Tigray regional president Debretsion Gebremichael is not dead
author: PesaCheck
description: Debretsion Gebremichael appeared on Tigray TV on 6 December 2021.
articleBody:
A 3 December 2021 video shared on Facebook claiming that Debretsion Gebremichael, the president of the Tigray region, is dead, is FALSE.

“Breaking news. Debretsion’s funeral. Mekelle burst into tears,” the text of the video says in Amharic. It claims Debretsion’s funeral ceremony was held in Mekelle and the Tigray forces were concealing information about his death.

However, Debretsion appeared on Tigray TV on 6 December 2021, days after the death claims were made.

PesaCheck debunked similar death claims about Debretsion on 28 October 2021 and 29 October 2021, as seen here and here.

The Ethiopian National Defence Force has been at war with Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) forces in the north of the country since November 2020.

Some TPLF leaders have been killed as a result of the war.

Initially, the war was confined to the Tigray region, but it expanded to the Afar and Amhara regions. In early November 2021, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed announced he would go on the battlefront and it has since been reported that the Ethiopian government has recaptured many areas under Tigray Forces control.

PesaCheck has looked into a video post shared on Facebook on 3 December 2021 claiming the death of the Tigray region president, Debretsion Gebremichael, and finds it to be FALSE.

headline: PesaCheck and Facebook partner to fight misinformation in Kenya
author: PesaCheck
description: The partnership will see PesaCheck work with Facebook to add more context to the posts on the platform.
articleBody:
Facebook has partnered with PesaCheck, East Africa’s first fact-checking organisation, to launch third-party fact-checking in Kenya to verify the accuracy of news being disseminated on its platform.

Along with PesaCheck, Facebook is also working with Africa Check and AFP in Kenya to verify content on the platform.

PesaCheck was established in 2016 to verify the often confusing numbers quoted by public figures across East Africa to empower citizens to better understand public finances and make better informed decisions during participatory budget-making processes.

PesaCheck has since grown its focus to include election fact-checking, as well as claims related to how governments are delivering on public services such as health, education, water and sanitation.

The new Facebook partnership builds on PesaCheck’s membership of the International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN), and its Code of Principles, which commits fact-checking organisations to non-partisanship, fairness and transparency, as well as an open and honest corrections policy.

PesaCheck joins a global network of 28 other fact-checking organisations worldwide who are certified by the IFCN and have partnered with Facebook to help detect and debunk misinformation in their countries.

“Part of our strategy is partnering with third-party fact-checkers to review and rate the accuracy of articles and posts on Facebook”, Tessa Lyons, Facebook Product Manager, explains. “These fact-checkers are independent and certified through the non-partisan International Fact-Checking Network. When these organisations rate v as false, we rank those stories significantly lower in News Feed. On average, this cuts future views by more than 80%. We also use the information from fact-checkers to improve our technology so we can identify more potential false news faster in the future.”

Data from Portland Communications indicates that 49% Kenyans got their news about elections in August and October 2017 from social media. A number of high-profile cases during this period exposed the extent of inaccurate and often deliberately misleading information distributed on social media.

“Our partnership with Facebook will allow PesaCheck to help combat misinformation by spotlighting information that could distort public discourse if left unchallenged. We will focus on local Kenyan content, including photos and videos, checking for factual accuracy,” says PesaCheck managing editor Eric Mugendi. “It gives us an opportunity to use innovative new ways to help people understand whether the content in their feed is credible, or not.”

If content is found to be false by PesaCheck or any of the other fact-checking organisations, Facebook will lower its ranking on News Feed, significantly reducing its distribution.

Additionally, Facebook will notify anyone looking to share a story that has previously been found to be false that the article was checked by one of the third party fact-checkers, which is a significant step in reducing the potential spread of misinformation.

Facebook’s content rating system has eight possible ratings that can be assigned to a fact-checked link. Content will be rated False if the primary claim is factually inaccurate. This generally corresponds to “false” or “mostly false” on the claims PesaCheck has looked into in the past. Content that is a mix of accurate and inaccurate claims, or where the primary claim is misleading or incomplete will be marked as Mixture. This corresponds with the ‘Inconclusive’ rating on the PesaCheck meter. Where the primary claim is factually accurate, the content will be marked as True, corresponding with the “true” or “mostly true” rating on the PesaCheck meter.

By partnering with Facebook, third party fact-checking organisations like PesaCheck are helping to sort fact from fiction. Considering that one in five Kenyans gets their daily news from social media, this is a good chance for all the organisations involved to make fact-checking more mainstream in Kenya.

headline: How PesaCheck works
author: PesaCheck
description: [Updated: 18 December 2020]
articleBody:
PesaCheck is headed by a publisher, who is also CfA’s chief executive officer (and co-founder). The publisher drives organisational strategy, and partnerships. The newsroom is led by a managing editor, who is the senior editorial decision-maker and who is responsible for shaping editorial priorities and signing-off on all fact-checks before publication. The managing editor is assisted by three deputy editors; a news editor who manages the NewsDesk and in-country researchers/fact-checkers across the continent; a chief copy editor who manages the multilingual CopyDesk that uses a three-step process to check all fact-checks for factual accuracy and grammatical correctness; and a special projects editor who oversees PesaCheck’s digital innovations including our DebunkBot, PromiseTracker, PesaYetu and TaxClock toolkits.

The editors are supported by deputies (including Francophone and Amharic language team coordinators), as well as newsdesk-based specialist data analysts/researchers.

The PesaCheck newsdesk receives additional support from CfA’s wider data journalism and infographic design teams, as well as its digital engagement (social media and multimedia) team. And, PesaCheck works closely with CfA’s Academy to help mentor and train other newsrooms or civic watchdogs.

Our researchers

PesaCheck’s editorial team is composed of fact-checkers who have extensive journalistic experience, or who are research specialists in topics such as economics, public finances or development issues.

Our fact-checkers are always locally based, in the 12 countries we report from, in Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Côte d’Ivoire, Ethiopia, Guinea, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Tanzania and Uganda. We also run a Francophone regional support hub in Senegal.

The fact-checkers regularly collaborate on regional verification projects, tackling cross-cutting thematic issues such as the COVID-19 health emergency, or assisting each other as part of ‘rapid response teams’ during civil wars/conflicts/coups and during the run-up/polling during elections.

PesaCheck occasionally appoints additional specialists, as short-term ‘fellows’ or associates, to drive specific projects such as our research into persistent conspiracy theories on YouTube or the spread of toxic speech (such as racist incitement and other hate speech) on WhatsApp.

PesaCheck’s fact-checkers focus on verifying the accuracy and meaning of the actual content in mis-/disinformation claims. Another CfA initiative, the iLAB at ANCIR, uses data science and forensic investigation to probe the ‘hidden hand’ networks and digital techniques used to make misleading content go viral. PesaCheck often collaborates with the iLAB and another CfA incubated initiative, the Digital Forensic Labs (DFRLab) Africa team, to expose large-scale coordinated inauthentic behaviour (CiB) and influence operations.

More information on the core PesaCheck team can be found here.

Our sources

There is a lot of mis-/disinformation and other misleading content out there. This includes claims by public figures and pundits at public events and in the mainstream media (in print media, or on TV and radio, and on their online outlets), as well as on government or political party websites, on social media (including on chat platforms such as WhatsApp) or blogging and multimedia sites such as YouTube.

PesaCheck believes it is important to apply a consistent set of criteria for determining eligibility for us to fact-check public claims, so that we can be consistently even-handed in our approach.

We also collect requests from the public on claims that need checking using this online form.

As a requirement for all our fact-checks, we include multiple sources of information and references. This helps to underline the veracity of our arguments. In addition, the sources are referenced accurately. To do this, we use sourceAFRICA, a repository of actionable documents.

Through sourceAFRICA, the PesaCheck team can:

Archive the source documents for future reference
Annotate the specific page where the information is sourced from. As newspapers do not use complete references like academic papers, hyperlinks would serve to highlight the references. It also allows the readers an opportunity to review the document in its entirety.

Every source document that is referenced in a story is saved on sourceAFRICA in order to preserve a copy and link directly to the information being referenced.

All sources and facts to be checked will be recorded on Check, where fact-check requests crowdsourced from the public and from social media will be managed and updated as they progress.

We put a premium on story ideas generated by members of the public, as this indicates that the issue is of great public importance, and it is a good source of information that may not yet be in the public eye.

To underline the credibility of PesaCheck stories, we ensure that our sources are quoted comprehensively — full name and designation.

Any information from sources that seek anonymity is treated as background information only. Such information must be corroborated by evidence.

PesaCheck is committed to disclosing to its readers the sources of the information in its stories to the maximum possible extent. We want to make our reporting as transparent to the readers as possible so they may know how and where we got our information. Transparency is honest and fair, two values we cherish.

Identifying claims to be checked

Not all statements are created equal. Here are some criteria that we use to help establish a hierarchy of important statements to fact-check:

Members of the public can also suggest claims to be fact-checked, by emailing us at [email protected] or reach the news editor at [email protected] They can also WhatsApp out tipline: +254754999992. If claims from the public meet the public interest criteria, they’ll be looked into, and feedback provided on the channel it was shared.

Fact-checking guidelines

We have three main rules guiding our fact-checking process:

Golden Rule 1: Only one fact per fact-check. We limit each fact check to one statement only, or a set of statements that are clearly related.
Golden Rule 2: Check every fact check. We do our best to corroborate the fact/verification. For example, rather than using a newspaper story about the budget; we use the budget document to fact check a statement.
Golden Rule 3: Draw a conclusion based on the facts. After all the research, corroboration and interviews, we assign a label to the fact check: True, Partially True, Untrue, Partially Untrue, or Inconclusive.

We use this checklist to write and prepare our fact-checks:

Is the statement being checked included verbatim?
Is there an explainer for why this statement was selected for checking?
Has the category of deception been identified?
Have all the sources for the fact being checked been identified?
Any source documents used in the fact check need to be annotated and uploaded to sourceAfrica, including any additional useful data identified in the process of fact-checking.
Has the reason for the labeling the statement True, Not True, etc been indicated?
Is the label (true, not true etc) mentioned briefly at the top of the story, and in more detail at the end of the story?
Have any links to the sources and the statement being checked been included in the body of the article?

Final editing checklist

We use the following final editing checklist based in part on the PolitiFact checklist:

1. Is the claim open to interpretation? Is there another way to read the claim?

2. Is the rating fair and consistent with other fact checks?

3. Is the rating supported by all available facts? Do questions linger?

Social media policy

Social media is a key tool that we use to distribute our fact-checks. The following are guidelines that we use to keep our social media consistent and harmonised.

We don’t post anything that we cannot stand by.
All posts follow a consistent structure — a question statement (what), a source (who) and a link to the story (where to find more).
Example: FACT CHECK: Did @Kandie_Phyllis misspeak about pledging Sh18bn for disabled kids? @PesaCheck finds out: p://bit.ly/2aIxrqa
Each fact check needs a standard hashtag, for example #PesaCheck
All reactions and comments are looked into, especially when they lead to potential follow-up stories that may arise out of the fact check.

Corrections policy

Transparency is a core value for PesaCheck, and we strive for accurate and comprehensive fact-checking. We all make mistakes sometimes, and while every error is a weakness, some errors are inevitable, and we are fully open to correcting them promptly in whatever material we publish on our platforms.

When we run a correction, clarification or editor’s note, our goal is to tell readers, as clearly and quickly as possible, what was wrong and what is correct. Anyone should be able to understand how and why a mistake has been corrected.

It is necessary to use a correction, clarification or editor’s note to inform readers whenever we correct a significant mistake.

Updates are used to reflect important new information or clarifications; corrections are for mistakes.

Clarification

When the content is factually correct but the language used to explain the facts is not as clear or detailed as it should be, the post will be rewritten and a clarification added to the story. A clarification can also be used to note that we initially failed to seek a comment or response that has since been added to the story.

Editor’s notes

A correction that calls into question the entire substance of an article, raises a significant ethical matter or addresses whether an article did not meet our standards, may require an Editor’s Note and be followed by an explanation of what is at issue.

Therefore:

When an error is brought to our attention, we will indicate in comments that it has been corrected.
Any erroneous information published on our social platforms will be corrected on any and all platforms it was published on.
We do not attribute blame to individuals, but we may note that an error was the result of incorrect information from a trusted source.

Take-down (unpublish) requests

As a matter of editorial policy, we do not grant take-down requests. If the subject claims that the story was inaccurate, we are prepared to investigate and, if necessary, publish a correction.

Stories will be updated if we checked a claim and drew a conclusion based on facts available at the time, but there is significant new information that will warrant a change in that conclusion.

In short, our response will be to consider whether further action is warranted, but not to remove the article as though it had never been published.

Right of reply

Persons who are the subject of a fact-check get a reasonable opportunity to respond to us.

Attribution

We strive to be truthful about the source of our information. Facts and quotations in a story that were not produced by our own reporting need an attribution. Attribution of material from other media must be total. Plagiarism is not permitted.

We place a premium value on original reporting.

headline: FALSE: This image does not show TPLF, Sudanese or Egyptian troops trying to enter Ethiopia
author: PesaCheck
description: The image has been uploaded to different websites since 2020 and is associated with reports of the border dispute between Ethiopia and…
articleBody:
An image posted on Facebook with a claim that it shows the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), along with Sudanese and Egyptian troops attempting to enter Ethiopia through Sudan is FALSE.

The post is accompanied by text in Amharic that reads in part,

“Action was taken by the Ethiopian Coalition forces on the troops trained in Sudan and sent to Ethiopia by TPLF. The TPLF was trying to deploy 6,000 troops, including Sudanese and Egyptian troops, through Sudan. Following these Sudan is telling the Ethiopian and Eritrean joint forces were attacking its troops,” parts of the post in Amharic reads.

However, Google reverse image search results reveal that the image has been used on different websites since 2020.

For instance, the image was published on the Hawar News Agency website on 18 December 2020 in an article: “Sudanese army declares control over all Sudanese lands.” Similarly, the image was used, as seen here and here, on the Archyde and Somali Guardian websites in their report about border disputes between Ethiopia and Sudan.

The Ethiopian government has said that it destroyed TPLF troops trying to enter Ethiopia through the Sudan border. But it did not mention the involvement of Sudanese and Egyptian armies. Also, the Sudan Tribune reported the attack yet it did not mention Eritrean troops involvement.

Ethiopia and Sudan have a border dispute over Al-Fashaga, fertile agricultural land. However, the image under investigation does not show the recent fighting between the two countries.

PesaCheck has looked into a Facebook image claiming to show TPLF, Sudanese, and Egyptian troops who are trying to enter Ethiopia through Sudan and find it to be FALSE.

headline: SCAM: This website giving away KSh 7,000 Safaricom gift vouchers is a hoax
author: PesaCheck
description: There is no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s official website.
articleBody:
A website claiming to belong to Safaricom, and promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers is a SCAM.

Before being awarded the gift voucher, respondents have to answer a set of questions about themselves and their opinion of the Safaricom brand.

After completing the questionnaire, the user is informed that they have won a KSh 7,000 gift voucher. The only caveat is that they have to share the promotion with either five groups or 20 friends on WhatsApp.

“Share it until the blue bar is full!” a pop-up on the page reads.

This fact-checker pressed the ‘WhatsApp’ share button until the bar turned blue. The next step is to click the buttons ‘activate’ and ‘verify’. Verification is by keying in your phone number.

“Click activate and complete the given task, verification is by phone number or downloading, registering e.t.c. (Remember, this step is very important, add your phone number to verify),” the pop-up box reads.

This appears to be a phishing scam aimed at obtaining people’s personal information.

Clicking on the ‘activate’ and ‘verify’ buttons redirects to unrelated websites. One is an e-commerce site and the other is a Jumia black Friday promotion site.

To confirm whether the website we are fact-checking belongs to Safaricom, we visited the telecom’s verified Twitter account and clicked on the link on their bio. The link landed us on a completely different website.

We performed a WhoIs search of the two websites to verify the legitimate Safaricom website. WhoIs results show that the website being fact-checked was registered on 11 October 2021 under the domain name “mpesaken.gifts” in Iceland (IS).

Safaricom’s website, whose link is contained on the company’s verified Twitter account, was registered on 12 February 2003 under the domain name “safaricom.co.ke” in Kenya.

Scrolling through the official Safaricom website, did not return any cash giveaway. There is also no cash giveaway on Safaricom’s verified Twitter account or Facebook page.

PesaCheck has looked into a website claiming to belong to Safaricom, promising to give gift vouchers worth KSh 7,000 to its customers and finds it to be a SCAM.

headline: ALTERED: This image of fighters with the Oromo Liberation flag is doctored
author: PesaCheck
description: The original image shows Somali Al Shabaab fighters gathering in February 2012.
articleBody:
An image post of armed personnel in which a Facebook user claims it shows the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) soldiers is ALTERED.

The post in Amharic has a headline that says, “the OLF Shane group has been eliminated”.

“OLF shene, the group that allied with TPLF Junta to destabilise the country has been operating in some of Oromia regions, but its mission is being aborted,” the post reads in part, adding “irreversible actions were taken against the destabilizing force which planned to carry out terrorist actions in East Guji, Negelle Borana and Arsi Negelle areas”.

The photo shows an armed group in military uniform standing in two lines, their heads covered with black scarves, while one holds up an OLF flag.

The names OLF Shane and Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) are widely used to refer to an armed group fighting against national troops in the Oromia regional state.

Reports by the Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation, a state-owned broadcaster, seen here, here and here, say that coordinated action had been taken by Federal Police and Oromia special forces against OLF Shane on 8 December 2021.

The social media user copied the state broadcast news and shared it along with the image in the post.

However, the attached image does not show OLF Shane or OLA, as claimed.

Google reverse image search results show that the image shows a gathering of Somali Al Shabaab fighters in February 2012. The photo has been used in multiple news stories since then.

The image was captured by AFP photographer Mohamed Abdiwahab on 13 February 2012 at Elasha Biyaha in Somalia. The description of the image provides that the image is of “Somali Al Shebab (sic) fighters” gathering in Elasha Biyaha, in Somalia, after a demonstration to support the merger of Al Shebab and the Al-Qaeda network.

The original image was digitally manipulated and the Al Shabaab fighters’ flag was replaced by that of the OLF.

PesaCheck has investigated an image shared on Facebook claiming to show fighters of the Oromo Liberation Army and finds it to be ALTERED.

headline: FALSE: These photos do not show roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention
author: PesaCheck
description: The images of roads in the tweet are from Brazil and Uganda.
articleBody:
A tweet with images claiming to show a before and after look of the roads in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) after Uganda’s intervention is MISLEADING.

The tweet reads; “DR Congo Roads before Uganda intervention vs soon after our intervention. #LetsBuildUG”.

The image purporting to show DRC before Uganda’s intervention is a dirt road in which several vehicles are stuck, while the one claiming to show the aftermath of Kampala’s intervention is a tarmacked road with limited traffic.

However, a Google reverse image search shows the first photo was taken from the Amazon region in Brazil. The image has been featured in several publications online, including here, here and here.

The search also reveals that the image was taken on the Trans-Amazonian highway. This 5,000-kilometre road cuts across the heart of the Amazon forest, spanning Brazil from the coastal city of João Pessoa in the northeast to the border with Peru.

A Google reverse image search shows the second picture was taken from Uganda in Mpigi District. The Uganda National Roads Authority first shared the photo on Twitter, showing the Mpigi — Kanoni road project.

The post follows Uganda’s announcement of a plan to build 223km of roads in neighbouring DRC, premised on boosting trade between the two countries. However, none of the images above shows a road in the DRC.

PesaCheck has looked into a tweet with images claiming to be taken from the Democratic Republic of Congo before and after Uganda’s intervention and finds them to be FALSE.

headline: FALSE: Ignore this message inviting applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya — it is fabricated
author: PesaCheck
description: The automobile marketer has disowned the message and confirmed that it is fake.
articleBody:
A Facebook post asking job seekers to submit applications for vacancies at Isuzu Kenya is FALSE.

The company is urgently looking for technicians, the post states, and those with a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering are eligible to apply. The email address given for communication appears to be hosted on the same domain as the actual Isuzi Kenya domain — isuzu.co.ke and interested candidates are asked to send their applications to the address.

“If you happen yo (sic) know anybody with a KNEC diploma in mechanical engineering, Automotive or production options with a minimum score of C- (Minus) kindly assist them to forward their photocopy documents to: ISUZU E.A (Formerly General Motors) for shortlisting. Please treat this with maximum urgency as technicians are urgently required,” reads the message.

The message has also been shared here.

However, there is no information about the job opportunity on the company’s website, its Facebook and Twitter accounts.

In a Facebook post on 6 December 2021, the company disowned the message, terming it as fake.

Additionally, applications for job opportunities at Isuzu Kenya are sent to [email protected] and not to specific individuals as claimed.

PesaCheck has examined a message calling on job seekers to submit applications for jobs at Isuzu Kenya, and finds it to be FALSE.
